properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 30 to 60 millimetres of rain by Tuesday morning. Periods of rain are expected to begin in deep southwestern Ontario by midday today and then spread northeastwards, reaching southern Georgian Bay by early this evening. The rain is expected to taper off early Tuesday morning, although some uncertainty remains around when the rain will end. Total rainfall amounts ranging from 30 to 60 millimetres are expected, with locally higher amounts possible in thunderstorms. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation closely. Rainfall Warnings may be issued if additional rainfall appears likely. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-18T05:27:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-17T13:28:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2989734255.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 25 to 50 millimetres of rain by Monday night. As of noon, periods of rain have begun in Windsor and will spread northeastward across all regions this afternoon. Rain is expected to continue overnight and Monday. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 millimetres are forecast with potential for locally higher amount in thunderstorms. The rain will taper off by Monday night in most places. However, in areas near the Michigan border, rain may persist into Tuesday with additional rainfall amounts possible. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation closely. Rainfall Warnings may be issued if additional rainfall appears likely. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-18T16:50:07-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Unsettled weather pattern with potential for heavy rain today and tonight. A frontal system will track across southern BC this morning. In its wake, an unstable atmosphere will give conditions favourable for afternoon showers and thunderstorms that may persist through tonight. Total rainfall amounts of 10 to 20 mm is possible by Monday morning. High streamflow advisories are currently in effect for these regions of the BC interior. They can be found at: http://bcrfc.env.gov.bc.ca/warnings/index.htm . ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-18T02:45:15-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near 50 millimetres of rain is likely by late Monday afternoon with locally higher amounts possible. Rain will begin late this afternoon. Rain is expected to be heavy at times tonight and Monday before tapering to a few showers late Monday afternoon.. Rainfall amounts near 50 millimetres are forecast with the potential for locally higher amounts in thunderstorms. Ponding of water on the roads may occur. As well, caution is advised near creeks and streams. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A winter storm will move from the Canadian Prairies into Hudson Bay on Tuesday, spreading heavy snow and freezing rain along coastal regions of the Kivalliq to Southampton Island. There is still some uncertainty with this system, however early indications are that some snow, followed by a significant freezing rain event is possible for Arviat and Coral Harbour. Freezing rain may also be possible in Chesterfield Inlet and Rankin Inlet. North of the band of freezing rain, moderate to heavy snow will develop with accumulations of 10 to 15 cm. This watch will be updated within the next 24 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-18T11:36:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-17T19:37:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0357025276.2020
Area: Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet, Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant ice build-up due to a long-lasting period of freezing rain is expected or occurring. A significant freezing rain event will develop over southern portions of the Brochet and Tadoule Lake regions tonight, then spread northwards and eastwards through the day on Monday. The freezing rain at any one location could last from as little as 6 hours to as much as 24 hours. Total freezing rain accumulations could reach as high as 20 to 25 mm in some locations. In Churchill, the freezing rain will likely begin early Monday morning and persist through the day. Although temperatures will climb towards freezing, a persistent northeasterly wind off of Hudson Bay will likely keep precipitation as freezing rain through the day. The precipitation will ease through Monday night with temperatures gradually climbing above 0C by Tuesday morning. Freezing rain accumulations in Churchill could reach as high as 10 to 15 mm. Further west, the event will begin earlier, and has the potential to be more intense. The hardest hit area by this system will be over southern areas of the Tadoule Lake region, where the freezing rain will begin on Sunday night and persist for nearly 24 hours before tapering off on Tuesday evening. Freezing rain accumulations will likely reach 15 to 25 mm across the region. In the Tadoule Lake townsite, the event will occur mainly on Monday night into Tuesday morning with 5 to 10 mm accumulation. Brochet will experience the least severe event, limited by milder temperatures and lighter precipitation. Freezing rain will develop over the southeastern corner of the region on Sunday night and push northwards Monday into Tuesday with likely accumulations of 2 to 5 mm. The location and intensity of freezing rain will be very sensitive to the exact track of this system as well as small changes in temperature. This warning may be updated as the system develops with changes to expected locations and/or amounts. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-18T12:41:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-17T20:42:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3475128655.2020
Area: Brochet, Tadoule Lake, Churchill
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Minimum temperatures: near zero. Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: overnight and early Monday morning, and again on Tuesday morning. Remarks: Frost is expected to form tonight as clearing skies and light winds coincide with cool temperatures, especially in low lying areas. Frost conditions are expected to be met Monday night into Tuesday morning as well. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-18T10:52:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-17T18:53:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0390900260.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for heavy rainfall continues through Monday morning 5 to 15 mm of rainfall has fallen across the southern interior since early this morning, A moist and unstable atmosphere over the southern BC interior tonight will continue to provide favourable conditions for showers and thunderstorms. The possibility of locally heavy downpours will continue through Monday morning. Further rainfall amounts of 5 to 15 mm are expected tonight. High streamflow advisories are currently in effect for these regions of the BC interior. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wet, cool, and windy Victoria Day for the GTA. Rain is expected to develop across the GTA this evening and continue through the holiday Monday before tapering off Monday night. Total rainfall amounts of 25 to 40 mm are expected with the potential for 50 mm over portions of the western GTA. Cool easterly winds will keep temperatures in the 10 to 12 degree range Monday. This is well below below the normal high of 20 degrees for this time of year. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Update-Wildfire Emergency Advisory Alert Is Being Issued By The Rm Of Torch River #488
properties.Summary:
Description: Update for the wildfire emergency advisory alert is being issued by the RM of Torch River #488, due to wildfire that has serious potential to cause emergency situations to the public. The wildfire is currently burning along the southwest edge of the RM of Torch River, from range road 2185 west to range road #2220, not along the north west edge of the RM of Torch River #488 Potential for heavy smoke in the communities of Smeaton, Snowden and Shipman.
